# Single source shortest path algorithm migration guide

%md
## Neo4j graph algorithms library

msg.data: Neo4j graph algorithms library

paragraphs.text:
%neo4j_algo
MATCH p=(:Place)-[:EROAD]->(:Place)
RETURN p

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Stream weighted shortest-path algorithm

We can execute the Weighted Shortest Path algorithm to find the shortest path
between Amsterdam and London like this

msg.data:
Stream weighted shortest-path algorithm

We can execute the Weighted Shortest Path algorithm to find the shortest path
between Amsterdam and London like this

paragraphs.text:
%neo4j_algo
MATCH (source:Place {id: "Amsterdam"}),
      (destination:Place {id: "London"})
CALL algo.shortestPath.stream(source, destination,  "distance")
YIELD nodeId, cost
RETURN algo.getNodeById(nodeId).id AS place, cost

msg.data:
place	cost
"Amsterdam"	0.0
"Den Haag"	59.0
"Hoek van Holland"	59.0
"Felixstowe"	59.0
"Ipswich"	59.0
"Colchester"	59.0
"London"	59.0

paragraphs.text:
%md

The quickest route takes us via Den Haag, Hoek van Holland, Felixstowe, Ipswich,
and Colchester! The cost shown is the cumulative total as we progress through the
cities. First we go from Amsterdam to Den Haag, at a cost of 59. Then we go from
Den Haag to Hoek van Holland, at a cumulative cost of 86—and so on. Finally, we
arrive in London, from Colchester, for a total cost of 453 km.

msg.data:

Den Haag to Hoek van Holland, at a cumulative cost of 86—and so on. Finally, we
arrive in London, from Colchester, for a total cost of 453 km.

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Stream un-weighted shortest-path

To have Neo4j’s Shortest Path algorithm ignore weights we need to pass null as the
third parameter to the procedure, which indicates that we don’t want to consider a
weight property when executing the algorithm. The algorithm will then assume a
default weight of 1.0 for each relationship

%neo4j_algo
MATCH (source:Place {id: "Amsterdam"}),
      (destination:Place {id: "London"})
CALL algo.shortestPath.stream(source, destination, null)
YIELD nodeId, cost
RETURN algo.getNodeById(nodeId).id AS place, cost

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

msg.data:
place	cost
"Amsterdam"	0.0
"Immingham"	1.0
"Doncaster"	2.0
"London"	3.0

paragraphs.text:
%md

### Calculate the un-weighted shortest path and work out the cumulative cost (weight) of the path

We could even work out the total distance of following this path by writing a bit of
postprocessing Cypher. The following procedure calculates the shortest unweighted
path and then works out what the actual cost of that path would be

msg.data:
Calculate the un-weighted shortest path and work out the cumulative cost (weight) of the path

We could even work out the total distance of following this path by writing a bit of
postprocessing Cypher. The following procedure calculates the shortest unweighted
path and then works out what the actual cost of that path would be

paragraphs.text:
%neo4j_algo
MATCH (source:Place {id: "Amsterdam"}),
      (destination:Place {id: "London"})
CALL algo.shortestPath.stream(source, destination, null)
YIELD nodeId, cost

WITH collect(algo.getNodeById(nodeId)) AS path
UNWIND range(0, size(path)-1) AS index
WITH path[index] AS current, path[index+1] AS next
WITH current, next, [(current)-[r:EROAD]-(next) | r.distance][0] AS distance

WITH collect({current: current, next:next, distance: distance}) AS stops
UNWIND range(0, size(stops)-1) AS index
WITH stops[index] AS location, stops, index
RETURN location.current.id AS place,
       reduce(acc=0.0,
              distance in [stop in stops[0..index] | stop.distance] |
              acc + distance) AS cost

msg.data:
place	cost
"Amsterdam"	0.0
"Immingham"	369.0
"Doncaster"	443.0
"London"	720.0

paragraphs.text:
%md

If the previous code feels a bit unwieldy, notice that the tricky part is figuring out how
to massage the data to include the cost over the whole journey. This is helpful to keep
in mind when we need the cumulative path cost.

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Neo4j graph data science library

msg.data: Neo4j graph data science library

paragraphs.text:
%md
Preferred way to use GDS library is with loaded named graphs, where we first load the graph into memory and then proceed to run algorithms on it.

msg.data: Preferred way to use GDS library is with loaded named graphs, where we first load the graph into memory and then proceed to run algorithms on it.

paragraphs.text:
%neo4j_gdn
CALL gds.graph.create('sssp_example', 'Place', {EROAD: {type:'EROAD', projection:'Natural', properties:'distance'}});

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Stream weighted shortest-path algorithm

We can execute the Weighted Shortest Path algorithm to find the shortest path
between Amsterdam and London like this

msg.data:
Stream weighted shortest-path algorithm

We can execute the Weighted Shortest Path algorithm to find the shortest path
between Amsterdam and London like this

paragraphs.text:
%neo4j_gdn
MATCH (source:Place {id: "Amsterdam"}),
      (destination:Place {id: "London"})
CALL gds.alpha.shortestPath.stream('sssp_example', {startNode:source, endNode: destination, relationshipWeightProperty: 'distance'})
YIELD nodeId, cost
RETURN gds.util.asNode(nodeId).id AS place, cost

After we are done with our analyisis we release the graph from memory

CALL gds.graph.drop('sssp_example')
